contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = White-throated Needletail | image =White-throated Needletail 09a.jpg | range_map =HirundapusCaudacutusDistribution.png | range_map_caption = <br/>{{legend0|#2BFF2B|Northern summer|border=solid 1px black}} {{legend0|#008000|Resident|border=solid 1px black}} {{legend0|#F5F338|Northern winter|border=solid 1px black}} | status = LC | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref name=IUCN2012>{{IUCN|id=106001750 |title=''Hirundapus caudacutus'' |assessors=[[BirdLife International]] |version=2012.1 |year=2012 |accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref> | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[Bird|Aves]] | ordo = [[swift|Apodiformes]] | familia = [[Apodidae]] | genus = ''[[Hirundapus]]'' | species = '''''H. caudacutus''''' | binomial = ''Hirundapus caudacutus'' | binomial_authority = ([[John Latham (ornithologist)|Latham]], 1802) }} The '''White-throated Needletail''' (''Hirundapus caudacutus''), also known as '''Needle-tailed Swift''' or '''Spine-tailed Swift''', is a large [[swift]]. It is the fastest-flying bird in flapping [[flight]], with a confirmed maximum of 111.6 km/h (69.3 mph).<ref name=BBC>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/earth/hi/earth_news/newsid_8539000/8539383.stm]</ref> It is commonly reputed to reach velocities of up to 170 km/h (105 mph), though this has not been verified.<ref name=trails>[http://www.trails.com/arts/amazing-bird-records.aspx trails.com]</ref><ref name=travelalmanac>[http://www.thetravelalmanac.com/lists/birds-speed.htm travelalmanac.com] Retrieved on 10 June 2009</ref><ref name=newton>[http://www.newton.dep.anl.gov/natbltn/200-299/nb215.htm Newton]</ref> These birds have very short legs which they use only for clinging to vertical surfaces. They build their nests in rock crevices in cliffs or hollow trees. They never settle voluntarily on the ground{{cn|date=June 2013}} and spend most of their lives in the air, living on the [[insect]]s they catch in their beaks. These swifts breed in rocky hills in central [[Asia]] and southern [[Siberia]]. This species is [[bird migration|migratory]], wintering south in the [[Indian Subcontinent]], [[Southeast Asia]] and [[Australia]]. It is a rare vagrant in western Europe, but has been recorded as far west as [[Norway]], [[Sweden]] and [[Great Britain]]. In June 2013, the bird was spotted in the United Kingdom, the first sighting in 22 years. The bird flew into a [[wind turbine]] and died; its body was sent to a museum.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2013/06/28/birdwatchers-flock-to-see-rare-bird-then-watch-it-killed-by-wind-turbine/ | title=Birdwatchers flock to see rare bird, then watch it killed by wind turbine| publisher=Fox News | accessdate=2013-06-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | author=Huyton, Harry | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/environment/blog/2013/jun/28/white-throated-needletail-wind-turbines | title=Let's not martyr the white-throated needletail to the anti-wind cause| publisher=The Guardian | accessdate=2013-07-01}}</ref> The White-throated Needletail is a mid sized [[bird]], similar in size to [[Alpine Swift]], but a different build, with a heavier barrel-like body. They are black except for a white throat, white undertail, which extends on to the flanks, and a somewhat paler brown back. The ''[[Hirundapus]]'' needletailed swifts get their name from the spiny end to the tail, which is not forked as in the ''[[Apus (genus)|Apus]]'' typical swifts. ==See also== *[[List of birds by flight speed]] ==References==<!-- Forktail13:109,16:147. Micronesica32:257. --> {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Commons category-inline|Hirundapus caudacutus}} *{{wikispecies-inline|Hirundapus caudacutus}} *{{field guide birds of the world|Hirundapus caudacutus}} *{{avibase|EA55CA2791012786|Hirundapus caudacutus}} [[Category:Hirundapus]] [[Category:Birds of Nepal]] [[Category:Birds of Pakistan]] [[Category:Birds of Tasmania]] [[Category:Birds of Western Australia]] {{Apodiformes-stub}} {{Link GA|de}} [[zh:白喉針尾雨燕]]
